Anti-Aliasing: All options do soften detail, compared to None, but all methods also do a good job addressing aliasing too, with some doing better than others
Texture Quality:
Low but go to Normal if you can

Low textures in City look okay, except for ground
Normal looks perfectly acceptable at 1152
Texture Filtering: 2x Anisotropic because there is a benefit to having it over Trilinear, but Trilinear isn't horrible
Shadow Quality: You really do want shadows on
Ray Traced Shadow Quality:
Medium

In some interior locations at least, Medium has a clear and significant impact. Outside this is not so much the case, likely because it is at High when the shadows from the sunlight are ray traced
Ambient Occlusion: it does help visually, gives more character to the environment. Can get away with it being off, but I would prefer it on
Depth of Field: always a personal choice, so Off is generally the minimum
Level of Detail:
Normal because of how it transitions.
Lowest is visually acceptable, but the pop-in is too apparent, as is Low

In at least one location though, Normal has too close a transition for how it interacts with shadows
Tessellation:
Don't need it on
Purely personal choice

Screenshot Difference
You'll notice it in screenshots, doubt you'll notice it in gameplay
Bloom: Always have the option to turn it off and you can
Motion Blur: Personal choice, can always be off
Screen Space Reflections:
Off because it isn't really necessary
It can have a significant impact though
Screen Space Contact Shadows:
Off because not strictly needed
perfectly acceptable
Pure Hair: Low is the lowest option, so yeah
Volumetric Lighting: The impact can be very apparent, so On if you can, but is not necessary
Lens Flares:
Don't need it on
Purely personal choice
Screen Effects:
Don't need it on
Purely personal choice

Anti-Aliasing: Based on the SSAA article, SMAA 4x does not add enough to make it worth it. SMAA, TAA, and SMAA T2x are good enough.
Texture Quality:
High is the max for 1152 (1080)
Ultra is not immediatley noticeable in City, perhaps at 1440/2160
Texture Filtering: It might really be 4x in some areas, but the ground textures are noisy enough I don't think high levels of Anisotropic are necessary
Shadow Quality:
honestly can't see how Normal is better, at least in the city

found a good example, Normal adds some blurring which is nice, but not strictly necessary. Ultra adds even more, but cann't spot benefit of High to Normal
Ray Traced Shadow Quality:
High

I did at times spot subtle changes between High and Ultra, but they were subtle enough to maybe be just above screenshot difference, but is still close enough that I want to keep to High
Ambient Occlusion: Can see the difference from BTAO, not always huge, but present so reasonable to have on
Depth of Field: reasoning given in game. High enables it in gameplay while Normal is "mainly for cinematics"
Level of Detail: High because it does provide a bit of a better transition than Normal, but not necessarily a 'must have'. Ultra is better, but I doubt most will notice it
Tessellation:
Nice to have on, does make an impact
Purely personal choice
Bloom: Really should have it on if you can
Motion Blur: Because it is a choice to have on, and does have an impact
Screen Space Reflections: On if you can because it is good to have
Screen Space Contact Shadows: Good effect to have, turn on (Normal) if you can. Cannot see impact of High
Pure Hair: Normal is noticeably better than Low. Also the highest option
Volumetric Lighting: Does make an impact, turn on if can
Lens Flares: Honestly can't tell you the difference
Screen Effects:
Nice to have on, does make an impact
Purely personal choice
